Ran across some fun little images that somebody posted. These instantly transported me to my childhood ... anybody else?

source (plus more images): https://imgur.com/gallery/tBJ0c

items.title: The one in which I test everything
items.content_html:
Testing Everything

I want to look at the features of Publii and see how well the WYSIWYG editor works (until I can figure out how/if to use Markdown).

Humankind. Be both.

That's a blockquote ... in case you can't figure it out tell. 

Center aligned ... obvi.

Reasons I'm liking this so far:

  • Keeps all my files local
  • Easy to setup and use
  • Fun to tinker (but works right out of the box so you don't have to)

Images are easy to upload ... I'll have to see where it stores them and how it looks in the post.

I recently re-signed up for a Todoist subscription. The free version works and has plenty of features, but I want the filters and labels ... which means I pay for the premium. This dude has a lot of great videos on how to get the most out of Todoist too.

OK, there are a lot of great features. I found in the settings where I was able to change the local location of the files/site too. So now it's sitting in my OneDrive local folder and will get backed up to the cloud as my backup. W00T!

items.title: Publii and Github pages
items.content_html:
I have been reading about the comeback of static blog sites. During the course of my research, I thought it might be more inline with the way I like to blog and do things. My current content management system (CMS) is Wordpress. It has a lot of features, thousands of plugins to extend functionality, and even more themes (paid and free). There is a thriving Wordpress community, so it's very easy to get up and running ... literally click a button to install in some instances.

At any rate, it's practical but not *fun* for me. I'm a tinkerer and like to know how things work. I've also been working with straight HTML for hundreds of years ... well, that's how it feels sometimes; so there's a familiarity and comfort level I like.

So a static site generator (SSG) basically is a framework that helps you create a whole site of static pages. It will build the "home page" with the list of posts, track tags, authors, etc. It's usually easier to theme as well. I tried using Pelican, a Python based framework; but had some issues in Windows. For the sake of time, I started searching for other options rather than troubleshoot more (which I may still go back and do eventually).

Enter Publii. It's a downloadable tool with a GUI that helps you manage your whole site (or sites). I've connected it to Github pages to host for free and am now testing it out. So let's see how this goes! In all honesty, I was hoping for a Markdown editor, just because I like that sort of thing, but this is very nice and easy so far ... we'll see.

items.title: 4in44
items.content_html:
Back in 2015 I tried a "Project 365" in which I would post a picture each day. I didn't really have a theme, per se. Some days I posted something I'd done that day, other days it was completely random. My goal was just to post a picture every day so I'd have something to look back on. Guess what? I haven't really touched it since then.

Last year, on my 44th birthday, for some reason I decided to try it again. But this time I upped the stakes and decided to post four pictures each day (hence the 4in44 tag … get it now?). A Project 365 can be a time consuming and difficult task sometimes; which is apparent when you look at some of my posts in which I clearly struggled to find things to photograph. But it is an interesting and fun thing to do and I recommend people try it sometime!

At any rate, this post isn't meant to dwell on the merits (or demerits) of a Project 365. Instead, I wanted to focus on how I did it. Hopefully you'll see that once you've got everything setup, all you really need to do is take the pictures.

Things you'll need:

  1. Camera or phone with a decent camera - I used an LG G4, iPhone 5, and finally my Pixel XL (we switched carriers last year and my phone was on backorder)
  2. A place to post the pictures - I used Instagram and Tumblr

Instagram
Instagram allows you to post single and multiple pictures per post. They also have several apps you can install separately which extend the Instagram functionality. I used their "Layout" app which lets you post a single picture collage with up to nine pictures in one collage. For my Project 365, I opted for four photos per day.

Regardless of which option you choose, I recommend you pick a tag that is unique and will allow you to easily find all your photos in the Instagram app. Plus, it's catchy and sets your pictures apart … a little.

You could certainly stop there. In fact, that's one of the easiest ways to participate in Project 365. I took it one step further so that I would easily be able to look back at my "year". Plus, Instagram made it super easy … just one more tap each day … to post my picture collage to my Tumblr site. You'll have to link your Instagram and Tumblr accounts, but let's get you setup on Tumblr first.

Tumblr
If you already have a Tumblr account that you use regularly, I recommend you setup a new Tumblr account specifically for this project. Instagram will only post to your main Tumblr blog. Tumblr lets you setup multiple blogs, but (as of this post) there is no way to select which Tumblr blog to which you post. So … a new account is best and easiest IF you want to keep your Project 365 separate from your main blog.

Once you've got your account setup, you'll jump back to Instagram and connect your account. If you setup Tumblr with multi-factor authentication (which I ALWAYS recommend you do whenever you can), you'll need to generate an "application password" in Tumblr. This is a one-time password that will only work to setup this connection.

Here are the steps on Android to connect Tumblr to Instagram (it may differ on other platforms):

  1. Visit your profile and hit the menu icon (vertical ellipsis)
  2. Then tap "linked accounts"
  3. Then tap "Tumblr"
  4. Next, enter your Tumblr credentials; remember to use the "application password" you create in Tumblr for multi-factor authentication

    Note: I also recommend you UNCHECK "follow blog.instagram.com" unless you really want to follow them on Tumblr

That's it, now you've connected Instagram to Tumblr. The next time you post a photo in Instagram, make sure you select to also post to Tumblr:

And then you'll see your photo on your Tumblr blog!

So, if you decide to use this route or not ... I would love to see your Project 365. Please share your links below! Also, if you care, here's the full 4in44 archive of photos from my 44th year on this planet.

items.title: Devoured by its own economic model
items.content_html:
This is actually a great article over at SBNation which is more about economics than the NFL and Football.

TL;DR - NFL franchises have become experts at "squeezing every profitable dollar, and trimming every wasteful one from the budget" making their teams more of an investment property that can coast on TV revenues. They're able to get others to pay for their stadiums too! They're masters of putting in just enough effort to keep fans interested in their team without having to actually produce anything good.

I feel like I'm seeing that trend in a lot of industries lately. Rush to the top, edging out every other competitor along the way ... then just coast along, sucking in the (almighty) profits.

And yet we, the consumers, continue to let them get away with it. "I've been an insert your team here fan my whole life ... I can't possibly support another team." Or, "I've been using products by insert favorite company here forever." And so on. Often times it's just easier to purchase one product over another, or go to one restaurant chain instead of another. I dunno ... there's no real "solution" that I know of ... I just thought it was a very astute article written about one subject that can be applied to others.

#ramblingoldfool

items.title: More like Alt-Wrong
items.content_html:
I'm a generally amicable person. I don't hold grudges well, I'm friendly, I try to look at both sides of an issue objectively. What I'm trying to say is that I feel like I'm a pretty even-keeled person.
 
But there is one thing that melts my cheese ... racial supremacists. The actions they take and the rights they think they have to incite violence all in the name of their message is beyond horrible.
 
Not once have I ever heard a rational, well thought argument for racial cleansing and/or nationalism. Never. It's not possible.
 
This piece in the New York Times, "Undercover with the Alt-Right" is frightening. It's good to read, but also leaves me feeling a little scared and hopeless. They sound so organized and there are enough uninformed and bigoted people in the world that their messages are getting some traction. How do we combat this? Anger and yelling just fuels their message. 
 
Once I've regained some of my mental fortitude, maybe I'll read the actual report from Hope Not Hate. Oof.

items.title: Recipe: Baked Apples
items.content_html:
Baked apples are a Fall tradition in our house. Every year since the kids were little we've gone apple picking. When you've got bags and bags of apples, you have to figure out a way to use them all. Apple pies are delicious, but a little labor intensive. I don't remember how we first started making these ... but once we did, it's become a regular "must have" in our house.

Without further ado, here's how we make baked apples ...

  • 4 apples - good for baking (Honeycrisp, Golden Delicious, etc.)
  • 2 C flour
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 1/2 tsp salt
  • 2/3 C. oil
  • 1/3 C. boiling water
  • brown sugar
  • butter

Preheat the oven to 375°. Core and peel the apples.

To make the dough, mix the flour, baking powder, and salt in a large bowl or mixing bowl. Mix the oil and boiling water together and stir briskly until well blended. Then pour the liquid into the flour mixture and mix until all blended together. You should have a nice ball of pie crust.

Split the crust into four equal parts (one part for each apple). Wrap the bottom and sides of each apple, leaving the top open for now. Make sure you reserve a small portion of dough to cover the tops later (see photo below). Place the apples into a baking dish (I use a glass 8x8 dish). Pour brown sugar in each core to the top, then pack it down. Put a dab of butter on top of the packed brown sugar, then fill the top with more packed brown sugar. Use the reserved bit of dough to cover the tops of the apples.

Bake for 30-45 minutes, but it really depends on the apples and how baked you want them. We like them pretty well baked and not very firm, so it takes longer. Use a fork to determine when they're done to your liking. We serve in a bowl with ice cream or vanilla flavored coffee creamer (particularly if you don't have ice cream in the house) poured over the top. Scrumptious!

items.title: A different world
items.content_html:
Note: I posted this originally on the Friendface ... but felt I should post it here too.

Found this photo on imgur. People watching the WTC burn 16 years ago.

I remember that day pretty vividly. I remember feeling like the world would change. And it has.

I hope we can all pull ourselves up by the collective bootstraps and learn to be nicer to each other. We're stuck on this planet together, we might as well.

Hug your loved ones. Say "hi" to your neighbors. Reach out to somebody who needs a hand right now. Stay safe.

Love you guys.

items.title: Vegan Garlic Alfredo Sauce
items.content_html:
I made this vegan garlic Alfredo sauce tonight ... and it was a hit!

The recipe is from "The Vegan 8", so it's only eight ingredients. I found it took a little longer than the recipe suggests to make. It took about double the time for me to render down the onion and garlic, but still not long altogether. Very easy to make too. Basically, you just render down the onion and garlic in some veggie broth. Then mix everything in a blender and add to pasta. It was creamy and garlicky ... just the way I like it. Don't forget to soak the cashews!

I'll repost the recipe here, but make sure you give some lover over at The Vegan 8 if you do use the recipe.

Ingredients:

  • 1 medium white onion, chopped (should be about 1 1/2 cups)
  • 2 cups vegetarian broth, separated
  • 1/2 tsp salt
  • pepper
  • 4 large cloves garlic, minced
  • 1/2 (heaping) cup raw cashews, soaked (soak overnight if you don't have a powerful blender)
  • 1-2 Tbsp lemon juice
  • 1/4 cup nutritional yeast

Instructions:

  1. Add the onion and one cup of broth to a large pan over medium-low heat. Cook about eight minutes or until onion is tender.
  2. After several minutes, add the garlic and cook until all the broth is evaporated.
  3. Put the cooked onion and garlic in the blender and add remaining ingredients (start with about 3/4 cup of remaining broth and add more as needed). Blend on high for a few minutes or until creamy and smooth.

The son went back for three servings ... and he's not vegan. So that should tell you all you need to know. winking smiley

items.title: Parade of the Wooden Soldiers
items.content_html:
I went to Arlington National Cemetery to visit my Oma today. She passed away almost seven months ago. I got much more emotional than I expected to, if I'm honest. But her headstone is complete now ... so it was a very nice visit.

There are things that keep popping up that remind me of her lately too ... like she's letting me know she's still around. The one that warmed my heart most recently was an article about a collection of 78rpm records being digitized on archive.org. I was randomly searching the archive and stumbled upon "Parade of the Wooden Soldiers." Oma used to play that song for me, back when she had her piano. Now I have her piano ... and the sheet music for "Parade of the Wooden Soldiers." Edit: I can't seem to get the embed to work, so just head over and listen to the song, dagnabit!

I think I need to learn that song ...
